This Thanksgiving season I hope folks in Congress remember the words of President Kennedy who said “As we express our gratitude we must never forget that the highest appreciation is not to utter words but to live by them.”

Folks shouldn’t have to wait any longer. It’s time for Senate Republicans to come to the table and agree to an adequate relief package to support the American people. No more gridlock. No more pausing.

>8 million Americans have fallen into poverty since May. W/ unemployment benefits expiring & stimulus payment seeming like a distant memory things will only get worse. That’s why the House passed a relief bill to extend unemployment assistance & provide another round of payments

During this economic crisis we’ve seen people lose jobs lose hours at work and lose income—all factors exacerbating the threat of homelessness. That’s why the House passed a relief bill to provide rental assistance and protections from eviction and foreclosure.
What’s more people shouldn’t be threatened with the loss of their housing because of this pandemic. Nearly 11 million households in America spend more than 50 percent of their income on housing.

To me simply put it is wrong that people are facing hunger this week. According to one nonprofit nearly 50M Americans could be food insecure this year – including 17M kids. That’s why the House passed a relief bill to provide nutrition assistance to reduce food insecurity.

Now more than ever Democrats and Republicans need to come together and craft a relief package that meets the needs of Americans who are hurting.   I have a sense of urgency about seeing a COVID relief bill pass.

In the House we’ve already passed two different bills in recent months aimed at these goals. Unfortunately the Senate has failed to act. Instead Leader McConnell has said “let’s pause.”   But the time for pausing has long needed to end.

I’m working hard in these final weeks of the year to get a comprehensive COVID-19 relief bill passed that will crush this virus provide assistance to folks who are unemployed or experiencing housing insecurity and help small businesses on Main Street.

It’s been 8 months since a comprehensive COVID-19 relief bill was last passed by Congress. It is shameful that more relief has not been provided to folks – and this Thanksgiving weekend I’m thinking about the people who need Congress to act.
